questions.question: 1. To study simple harmonic motion in the simulation, the value of the damping factor b is set to:

explanations.b: Incorrect. b = 2√2 produces critically damped motion.
explanations.c: Correct. Setting b = 0 removes all damping, giving pure simple harmonic motion.
explanations.d: Incorrect. b = 0.5 gives under-damped oscillations, not pure SHM.

questions.question: 2. While studying damped oscillatory motion, under-damped oscillations occur when the damping factor b satisfies:

explanations.a: Incorrect. b = 0 means no damping — this is pure SHM.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This condition gives critical damping.
explanations.c: Correct. When b < 2√2, the system oscillates with exponentially decreasing amplitude (under-damped).
explanations.d: Incorrect. This condition gives over-damped (non-oscillatory) motion.

questions.question: 3. In the experiment to calculate the spring constant k for a free oscillator, the angular frequency ω is obtained using:

explanations.a: Incorrect. 1/T gives ordinary frequency f, not angular frequency.
explanations.b: Correct. Angular frequency ω = 2πf, where f is the oscillation frequency read from the simulation.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This formula applies to the damped oscillator, not the free oscillator case.
explanations.d: Incorrect. b/2m is the decay constant γ.

questions.question: 4. Which of the following oscillations is classified as free oscillation?

answers.a: Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM) with b = 0 and F₀ = 0

explanations.a: Correct. Free oscillation means no external driving force and no damping — pure SHM.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Damped oscillation loses energy; it is not a free oscillation.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Forced oscillation requires an external periodic force.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Critical damping is a special case of damped motion.

questions.question: 5. In the forced oscillation experiment, the amplitude A of oscillation is calculated using which relation?

explanations.a: Incorrect. F₀·ω is not dimensionally consistent for amplitude.
explanations.b: Incorrect. F₀/k gives static deflection, not the dynamic amplitude.
explanations.c: Correct. This is the standard formula for steady-state amplitude of a driven damped oscillator.
explanations.d: Incorrect. m·ω² has units of force divided by length, not amplitude.

questions.question: 6. During the forced oscillation experiment, the driven angular frequency ω is set to 1.41 rad/sec. This is because:

answers.a: 1.41 is a standard default value with no special significance
answers.b: It approximates √2, close to the natural frequency ω₀ = √(k/m) = √2 for k = 2, m = 1
answers.c: It is above the critical damping threshold
answers.d: It ensures the system is always over-damped

explanations.a: Incorrect. The value is deliberately chosen to be near resonance.
explanations.b: Correct. √2 ≈ 1.414 rad/sec matches ω₀ = √(k/m) for k = 2 N/m and m = 1 kg, inducing near-resonance.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The critical damping threshold concerns the damping factor b, not ω.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Over-damping is controlled by b, not by the value of ω.

questions.question: 7. When the damping factor b is set to 3 in the simulation, the expected motion of the system is:

answers.c: Non-oscillatory; the system slowly returns to equilibrium

explanations.b: Incorrect. Constant amplitude occurs only without damping.
explanations.c: Correct. b = 3 > 2√2 ≈ 2.83 means over-damped; the displacement decays exponentially without oscillating.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Resonance requires the driving frequency to match ω₀.

questions.question: 8. In the experiment for the under-damped case (Case 2), the computed spring constant k uses the measured ω and the relation:

explanations.a: Incorrect. This applies only to the undamped case where ω = ω₀ = √(k/m).
explanations.b: Correct. Rearranging ω = √(k/m − b²/4m²) gives k = m(ω² + b²/4m²).
explanations.c: Incorrect. k = b·ω is dimensionally and physically incorrect.
explanations.d: Incorrect. ω/m does not give the spring constant.

questions.question: 9. If the initial position x₀ is changed during the free oscillator experiment (Case 1), which quantity changes?

explanations.a: Incorrect. ω₀ = √(k/m) depends only on k and m, not on initial displacement.
explanations.b: Incorrect. k is a property of the spring and does not change with x₀.
explanations.c: Correct. In SHM, the initial displacement x₀ sets the amplitude A of oscillation.
explanations.d: Incorrect. T = 2π/ω₀ is independent of amplitude in SHM.

questions.question: 10. In the forced oscillation experiment (Case 3), what happens to the amplitude A as F₀ is increased (with ω and ω₀ fixed)?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Increasing the driving force increases the steady-state amplitude.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Amplitude depends directly on F₀.
explanations.c: Correct. From A = F₀/(m√[(ω²−ω₀²)²+4γ²m²]), A ∝ F₀ when all other parameters are fixed.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Amplitude can only approach zero if F₀ → 0.
